description: Three small fragments (see figure) of a light limestone vertical deviating sundial, now in the City Antiquarium of Guidonia Montecelio, were found on different occasions in the countryside of Guidonia, a small town near Tivoli. The fractures of two of these pieces match, so they can be put together, while the third piece is from a different part of the sundial. The reassembled fragment is 115mm high, 200mm wide and 7mm deep. The dimensions of the detached fragment are 146mm by 16mm by 27mm. The noon hour line is completely missing, so it is difficult to make the usual calculations to determine the intended latitude. Consequently, the author has attempted an inverse procedure from the one normally followed when studying a sundial: the object was reconstructed starting from the reasonable hypothesis that it was built for the latitude of 42[Degree], the latitude in which it was found. The angle between the equinox line and the upper edge of the fragment, assumed to be horizontal, was measured and found to be 40[Degree], from which a deviation 49[Degree] west can be deduced. On the basis of these figures, the author made a drawing of a vertical deviating sundial which would seem to correspond quite well if the perpendicular height of the gnomon was about 130mm. In the example, the winter hyperbola appears higher than that calculated astronomically, a situation that is not rare in ancient sundials of imprecise workmanship. Through the reconstruction it was possible to identify, with good approximation, the position originally occupied by the third fragment, which contains a small part of the summer solstice curve. The shape of the cut stone slab must have been something like a triangle, with two straight sides - the upper horizontal and the noon vertical - and the third an arc approximately parallel to the summer solstice curve. It is clear, in fact, from the third fragment that this arc is not the result of a fracture but was carefully worked by the builder, who engraved an X in the concavity, rotated by 90[Degree] and delimited by two small vertical bars.

A light-coloured marble vertical deviating sundial, in a good state of conservation (see figure), was found on the site of some Roman buildings.  The sundial is inscribed with the winter solstice curve, completely preserved; the summer solstice curve, about half of which remains; and the equinox line, almost all of which remains. There are six hour lines. The usual methods of calculation give an intended latitude of about 39[Degree], little differing from that of the place where it was found, namely 42[Degree]. To judge from the slope of the equinox line, the face of the sundial probably deviated from the prime vertical by 36[Degree] west. The length of the gnomon, according to the calculations, was 58mm. The test of the distance along the equinox line between the noon line and the first hour after noon gave the following results: calculated 35mm, measured 44mm. Taking everything into account, the conclusion is that this sundial was built with a relatively good degree of accuracy.

Bonanome: The flat surfaces of this solar instrument have been carved and ârubricatedâ (i.e., coloured in red) to make their reading easier, since they acted as sequential dials. This means that a dial is designed to be faced to the East, in order to show the morning hours, whereas the other is faced to the West and shows the afternoon hours. On both surfaces, a mirrored pattern of vertical and horizontal lines called analemma reproduces the part of the daylight hours corresponding to the East and West cardinal points.  The line AEB marks the horizon, from where three different lines start. Two lateral hyperbolas, slightly declining, AAâ and BBâ mark the course of time during the solstitial period: it is shorter in the summer solstice (AAâ) around the 21st June, when the sun is on the highest point above the horizon, and longer in the winter solstice (BBâ), around the 23rd December, when the sun is on the lowest point above the horizon. Between those two lines there is the equinoctial line (EEââEâ), relating to the days of the spring equinox of the 21st March, and to the autumnal equinox of the 23rd September. This line is more or less inclined depending on the cardinal point the dial is facing. The six horizontal secant lines, starting from AEB and ending to AâEâBâ, after being calibrated on the Eastern and Western dials, mark the six sectors in which the hours are divided: in ante meridiem (a.m.) and post meridiem (p.m.) respectively. As we can see in the drawing, these six lines marking the passing of time are more clustered near the noon line because the sun moves slower in that phase. Therefore, the hour could be read looking at the tip of the shadow cast on the dial by the gnomon or style (that is the metallic element placed in a pre-arranged point of the analemma) which follows the motion of the sun across the sky. To determine the length, the position (orthogonal or inclined), the insertion point of the gnomon along the line AEB which marks the horizon, and to draw the declining segments crossed by the secant lines of the hours of the analemma, complex gnomonic calculations are required.  In the sundial we are discussing on, two gnomons have been placed halfway along the horizontal line AEB. Of these gnomons, only the pins still inserted in the marble slab and the lead used to solder them remain visible. Another characteristic of this sundial is the presence of a third gnomon. Similarly to the two other, it is marked by the soldering lead still present on the outer rim of the marble frame. Its insertion angle is particularly acute, probably due to the need of being in axis with the sun at noon of the equinoctial days. This, in turn, was probably devised to make calibration and periodic checks of the instrument easier.  However, at a closer examination, one can see that in the insertion point of this gnomon two straight carved lines intersect. They were once rubricated and are perpendicular: the vertical line is longer than the horizontal one because the dial border does not limit it. One can also see that the horizontal line must have continued to be overlapped onto the horizontal line of the Eastern analemma. Vice versa, the latter should have continued to reach the unfortunately damaged horizontal line of the Western dial. Since the point where the lines on the rim intersect is exactly the same as that of the third gnomon, it is more correct to believe that this system could have been used to follow the motion of the gnomonâs shadow from one dial to the other.  In other words, this system gave the observer the opportunity to read the time from below also during the delicate passage from the ante meridiem to the post meridiem position of the sun.

A Matelica si trova un raro modello di orologio solare in marmo bianco risalente, con incisioni, segni e scritture greche, detto âglobo di Matelicaâ. // Il Globo o Sfera fu rinvenuto, nel 1985, durante le fasi di consolidamento del Palazzo del Governo, nel pieno centro storico di Matelica. Il Globo Ã¨ costituito da una sfera, del diametro di 29 cm., di marmo greco cristallino. Su di essa sono incisi centri concentrici, linee, archi, lettere e parole greche. Il Globo Ã¨ un antichissimo orologio solare, adoperato per fare calcoli astrologici, astronomici e cronologici. Eâ un piccolo âcomputer di pietraâ che puÃ.b2 essere usato, con buona approssimazione, per calcolare le ore del giorno dal sorgere del sole, la data di Equinozi e Solstizi, il calendario e lâentrata del sole nelle varie costellazioni zodiacali. Il Globo Ã¨ una sorta di meridiana e deve essere esposto correttamente alla luce per poter offrire dati corretti: le zone di luce e di ombra vanno ad intersecare i segni e le linee incise sulla superficie  fornendo risposte corrette.

Il est en assez bon eetat de conservation, malgree lâabsence des ailes lateerales, brisees, et du gnomon, dont on devine lâemplacement par une cavitee de trois centimtres de profondeur. Il preesente onze lignes horaires gravees nettement dans la pierre, et trois courbes de deeclinaisons.

Du cadran, nâest conservee que la partie orientale de la surface reeceptrice. On nâobserve donc que les lignes horaires de lâaprÃ¨s-midi. Le fragment ne preesente aucune courbe solsticiale ou eequinoxiale.

Les extreemitees frontales et lateerales ont entiÃ¨rement disparues, le gnomon est bien eevidemment manquant, mais son emplacement est encore perceptible. Le cadran ne possÃ¨de toujours pas de courbes de deeclinaisons horaires (eequinoxiales et solsticiales) et preesente le reeseau habituel des onze lignes temporelles.

Sa forme est peu commune dans le corpus des cadrans romains, et sa reealisation technique trÃ¨s neegligee. Ainsi, il est difficile dâen deefinir la typologie, que nous laisserons volontairement Â«indeetermineeÂ». Lâarc gravee non loin de lâemplacement du gnomon est probablement deecoratif, il ne sâagit absolument pas de la courbe du solstice dâhiver. Les lignes horaires sont gravees de facon irreeguliÃ¨res, et ne sont pas espacees logiquement ni geeomeetriquement. Il en reesultait ainsi un fonctionnement trÃ¨s approximatif, loin des Â«canonsÂ» gnomoniques de lâeepoque.

On retrouve les onze lignes horaires ainsi quâun cercle intermeediaire, qui, comme pour le cadran de Vilanova, eevoque plus une repreesentation de la ligne eequinoxiale quâune reelle courbe de deeclinaison utilisable. Le centre du cadran nâest pas situee dans lâaxe du cÃ.b4ne comme il devrait lâÃªtre mais Ã  la base du gnomon Lâangle entre la face frontale et la verticale est de 29[Degree], ce qui ne correspond pas Ã  celui de Mazaracan, Ã  peu prÃ¨s 40[Degree]. La face frontale nâest ni perpendiculaire Ã  lâaxe de la terre, ni Ã  lâaxe du cÃ.b4ne. Lâensemble est donc trÃ¨s approximatif.
Seule la partie occidentale, preesentant les lignes post-meridiem, est conservee. Il ne semble pas y avoir de lignes solsticiales ou eequinoxiales.

Il est brisee au niveau des ailes lateerales. On observe cependant sur ce cadran une ligne, repreesentant apparemment la courbe eequinoxiale, qui joue plus un rÃ.b4le deecoratif que reellement scientifique. Les lignes horaires sont disposees de facon exacte sur la surface concave, mais ne sont pas dâune preecision remarquable.

description: La partie supeerieure de lâobjet preesente deux ailes lateerales oÃ¹ se trouve gravee un reeseau de lignes qui ne sont pas symeetriques et reeguliÃ¨res. La partie infeerieure, un pieedestal de forme circulaire, porte une inscription en lettres grecques, reedigee dans une langue ibeerique. This sundial has a surface which is separated in 12 parts representing 12 hours of the day. More particularly, the sundial consists of a hyperbola tracing the shadowâs path at the winter solstice, a second one for the summer solstice, and a straight east-west line in between marking the equinoctial shadows.  A line from the base of the gnomon to the south of the dial running due north denotes noontime. The hyperbola is centered on this noon line. The winter hyperbola opens to the north, the summer hyperbola to the south. In addition to the center noon line, additional oblique lines are added on either side to denote the hours of daylight before and after noon.

institution: Jordan Archaeological Museum, Jaba al- Qual.b4a

Il tracciamento delle linee lascia pensare ad un orologio di fattura abbastanza modesta e non Ã¨ escluso che posa trattarsi di un reperto di epoca molto tarda, forse anche bizantina, o addirittura altomedievale.

description: Am 16. August 1998 wurde beim Abbruch eines neuzeitlichen Hauses in Eretria eine Sonnenuhr gefunden und gleichentags in das Museum verbracht. Die Sonnenuhr war als Baumaterial in dem modernen Haus wiederverwendet worden, worauf auch die Beschaedigungen auf der Vorderseite des ansonsten in seinem antiken Bestand erhaltenen Marmorblocks zurueckzufuehren sein duerften. Weitere Spuren der Verbauung fmden sich vor allem auf der besser erhaltenen Schmalseite in Form einer feinen MÃ[Paragraph]rtelschicht. Der Fundort liegt auf dem Grundstueck 815 des Gesamtplanes von Eretria, im nÃ[Paragraph]rdlichen Teil der Unterstadt, nahe dem Akropolis-Suedfuss.  Da der Marmorblock, aus dem unsere Uhr gehauen wurde, mit Sicherheit als Import zu betrachten ist, kann zumindest nicht ausgeschlossen werden, dass die Uhr als Fertigstueck nach Eretria kam. Es scheint daher sinnvoller, eine Herstellung der Uhr in Eretria und fuer Eretria zu postulieren. Dafuer sprechen auch die nur sehr summarisch bearbeitete Rueckseite und die deutlich von der ansonsten rechteckigen Gesamtform des Blockes abweichende Linienfuehrung der Vorderseite. Dies scheint darauf hinzuweisen, dass die Sonnenuhr urspruenglich in einen architektonischen Zusammenhang eingegliedert war, was im uebrigen auch fuer die Kegelsonnenuhr von Patras angenommen wurde.

An der Peripherie der Platte sind drei fast konzentrische Kurven, mit den in Zwischenraeumen von 47 mm gestellten Zahlzeichen VII-XI, eingegraben; zentrales, rundes Loch zur Aufnahme des stiftfÃ[Paragraph]rmigen Sonnen- oder Schattenzeigers âgnomonâ.

The surviving part is a portion of the right half of the sundial (see figure). The oblique front forms an angle of 33[Degree] with the rear vertical plane, very different from the latitude of Nepi, which is about 42[Degree]. The noon hour line is almost completely missing. The hour lines from VII to XI and parts of the winter solstice and equinox curves are present. The remaining segments of the day curves are of equal length: 22 mm on the winter solstice curve, 35 mm on the equinox, and 64 mm on the circular intersection with the oblique front cut.  Because of the few elements available it is difficult to make any reliable calculations or any evaluation of how accurate this sundial may have been.

It was possible to measure the angle between the oblique front and the rear vertical plane, which is about 42[Degree], consistent with that of Torre Flavia. In spite of its poor state, three hour lines and two winter solstice and equinox arcs are still visible (see figure).

The top and left edges are in a very poor state, and most of the face containing the summer solstice curve has been lost.   The winter solstice line, approximately straight and almost parallel to the equator line, is cut in a much higher position than usual. The fragment shows five hour lines and a small portion of the summer solstice curve. The noon hour line is missing, unless it is the first of the hour lines, i.e. the one from which the incision of the equinox line starts. In this case, the fragment must be rotated slightly clockwise (see figure) to find what was probably its original position. This supposition is to some extent supported by the existence, on the left edge, of two cylindrical holes about 8mm in diameter and some 13cm apart. The upper one is 16mm deep, the lower 26mm. Assuming that they were originally of the same depth, the missing part of the slab must have been wider at the top, and its reconstruction would make the first straight cut line vertical. However, calculations based on this hypothesis, using the segments cut on the equinox line by the hour lines, are not sufficient to allow any reliable conclusion about the intended latitude of the sundial. Why the two holes were made is not clear. One possibility is that, as the equinox line shows a deviation to the west, this sundial might have been connected to another with a deviation to the east.

The absence of much of the noon hour line makes the usual calculations difficult. By a fairly easy reconstruction, however, the summer solstice curve gives an intended latitude of 32[Degree] while the winter solstice curve gives one of 34[Degree]. Both are very far from that of the site where the sundial was found, which is 42[Degree]. The angle between the oblique front and the rear vertical plane, which is 35[Degree], shows the same discrepancy, but agrees quite closely with the calculated latitude. There are eleven hour lines, with hour-points satisfactorily equidistant, while the solstice curves are almost equidistant from the equinox line â 95 mm and 101 mm respectively. From an analysis of the sum of the data measured and calculated, this sundial seems to be well cut but not without constructional irregularities.

It is an example of the rare case where the conical surface is cut quite perfectly, but all the geometrical details were added with poor accuracy. Accordingly, an ideal cone can be fitted with a half-aperture  of 24[Degree] and an axis inclined at 22[Degree] to the cut horizontal bottom plane and the top plane of the piece. The deviation of this inclination from the local latitude of 33[Degree] is still more evident if one considers the 17[Degree] by which the oblique southern front plane is inclined to the vertical, thus differing by 5[Degree] from the perpendicular to the axis. Furthermore, the only inscribed curve (see figure) intersecting the eleven hour lines defines a plane even closer to the vertical and so this by no means represents a seasonal day line. No explanation can be offered for this other than that we have an imitation of such a line (or of an auxiliary one according to Hueyttig's general interpretation). All the angles mentioned are uncertain by about [PlusMinus]2[Degree], mainly due to the loss of reference accuracy because the southern shoulders of the piece have been broken off. Another oddity may be seen in the fact that the joining point of the eleven hour lines lies considerably below the upper edge of the surface, where no trace of a gnomon-mounting is visible. A gnomon at that level would be geometrically acceptable but it would interfere with the reading of the first and last daily hours, while a gnomon at a higher level would avoid this problem but would impair the accuracy at any hour.

Lâoggetto conserva poco piÃ¹ della metÃ  della superfi cie concava sulla quale sono state incise le linee orarie. Delle undici linee orarie che dovevano dividere la meridiana in dodici parti (le ore temporarie in uso nel mondo greco e romano descritte nellâintroduzione) se ne vedono solo cinque, tra cui quella del mezzodÃ[Not]. Sono ben visibili le linee dei solstizi e degli equinozi, che attraversano le linee orarie: come di consueto in questo tipo di manufatti la curva del solstizio dâestate coincide con il bordo lavorato dellâoggetto. Lâalloggio delle linee orarie Ã¨ stato realizzato in modo sferico. Nella parte inferiore si nota il taglio della pietra che, in questo tipo di manufatti costruiti ad arte, corrisponde alla latitudine del luogo. Dallo studio del reperto (Fig. 4) appare una inclinazione che collocherebbe la meridiana ad una latitudine di circa 37[Degree], non compatibile con il luogo del rinvenimento o, in generale, con la fascia del centro Italia, ma con lâarea del Sud Italia o della Grecia.
institution: Museo di Storia Naturale di Livorno

description: The quarter sphere of Sundial 2 has suffered much greater damage than that of Sundial 3, but there are on its surface lines enough to indicate that the pattern originally inscribed thereon was a mirror image of that already described for Sundial 3. Damage to the stone has caused the loss of the exact location of the gnomon at each end as well as the method of their attachment. They were probably fixed perpendicular to the plane represented by the back of the limestone block at or near points X and Y where the radiate lines converge in each sundial. On each of the concave surfaces of Sundial 2 and Sundial 3 half of the dial pattern found on the reclining surface of Sundial 1 had been scribed except that the enumeration of the hours was reversed.

A unique clay object discovered at the site of Apollonia-Arsuf (Israel), which I claimed had been used as a horizontal (flat) portable sundial (horologium). The object is somewhat pentagonal, depicting a design that was incised (and partially stamped) on it prior to firing. Given its small dimensions, I rejected the idea that it could have served as a game board.  Due to its shallowness (some 0.15 m in depth) and design, I also rejected the possibility that it could have served as a mould for a metal object.
